snippets.text: Man After Man by Dooall Dixon is a
groundbreaking speculative evolution
story that spans 5 million years and
beyond.
It's the 24th century and the Earth has
been utterly wrecked by pollution and
overpopulation.
With this, a small number of humans are
chosen to leave the Earth in order to
colonize other planets. Jimes Smoot is
one such example. Two posthuman species
are created to aid in the construction
of the great spacecraft that will
transport them, the Aquamorphs and the
Vacuumorphs. The former were designed to
live and work underwater, and the latter
were designed to live and work in the
airless void of space. These subspecies
were fully sapient and able to engage in
complicated tasks, but they were bred to
be infertile. Once their work had been
completed, they lived on for a while
before perishing.
300 years hence. By this point, the
earth is beginning to recover and two
groups of humans have emerged. Those who
have adopted a more agrarian lifestyle
and remain as pure humans and the other
type, the high-techs. While the former
have effectively shunned advanced
technology and live simple, healthy
lives as farmers, the latter have come
about as a result of inbreeding and over
reliance on technology. They exist in a
fragile and degenerate state within
mechanical cradles that they use to move
around in. They never leave their homes
or go outside at all. But they are the
ones who, despite their physically
weakened state, move forward with the
genetic creation of new human forms.
Also present are the genetically
engineered aquatics, beings similar in
lifestyle to the now extinct aquamorphs.
These are the first creations of the
high-tech.
500 years hence, there are now four
additional species created by the
high-tech. Each one designed to live in
vastly different environments. The
tundra dwellers were made to live in the
colder snowy regions. the plains
dwellers who live on the grassy plains
of arid lands filling the niche left
behind by gazels, wilderbeast and water
buffalo. The forest dweller of course
lives in forested areas filling the
roles previously occupied by apes,
orangutans and sloths. And the temperate
woodland dweller fills the role of
creatures like deer, bears, and wolves.
With these five species having been
seeded throughout the Earth, humanity's
new course can begin. 1,000 years hence,
the high-tech have themselves changed a
great deal. They have managed to shed
the mechanical cradles and body parts
that kept them alive in ancient times.
Their outer shells are now comprised of
bloblike organic material with
additional limbs being added on or taken
away as current fashion dictates.
5,000 years hence. The temperate
woodland dweller has begun to recover
its lost sapiens. They can now build
rudimentary structures and have
developed the curious ability to inherit
memories from their parents. They have
become the memory people. Also present
during this time are the descendants of
the plains dweller called simply
migrants. The tropical tree dweller has
also now come into being itself a
descendant of the forest dweller. The
different branches are beginning to
emerge. 10,000 years hence, the tundra
dwellers and a subset of the temperate
woodland dweller descendants seem to
have formed a symbiotic relationship.
They have become the hunter carrier and
the hunter symbiant respectively. They
each seem to be comfortable enough with
each other, familiar enough with each
other to depend on each other for
survival. Also now in existence are the
hibernators, descendants of the
temperate woodland dwellers. The males
of this species hibernate during the
brutally cold winter months. The cave
dweller, another descendant of the
temperate woodland dweller, now
populates the subterranean caves and
tunnels, venturing to the surface at
night in order to hunt. 50,000 years
hence. Evolution never stops and three
new species are now roaming the
woodlands and the plains. The islander
is a species of humans rather small in
stature who inhabit the tropical
volcanic islands. The water seeker is a
chimpanzeeike species that has evolved
to detect water over vast distances.
Both of these are descendants of the
temperate woodland dweller. The communal
plains dweller is a descendant of the
migrants who first emerged around 45,000
years before 500,000 years hence. The
communal plains dweller has developed
further still in the ensuing 450,000
years, becoming a species known as the
social. They possess formidable blades
on their hands used for combat. The boat
person has also emerged by this point.
These are an evolved form of the memory
people who use their ancestral memory to
build boats that look very much like
those of their homo sapiens forebears.
1 million years hence, the aquatics have
evolved the ability to cover themselves
in a gelatinous coating which allows
them to venture out onto dry land. It
would seem that there is something
within them that compels them to return
to the terraneian world of their distant
ancestors. The aquatics are the ones to
watch out for. 2 million years hence,
various new forms have come into being,
each with its own unique adaptations for
the strange new future Earth that they
find themselves in. These include the
hiver, taller descendants of the socials
who get their name from their hive
building and hive mind state of being.
The parasites and hosts, a rather
grotesque situation, but one that seems
to work for all concerned, the
travelers, descendants of the boat
people who have continued the nomadic
lifestyle of their forebears.
And finally, the seeker, which is
descended from the water seeker. A
symbiotic relationship now exists
between the seekers and the hivers, who
utilize the seeker as a means to locate
water sources. 3 million years hence,
the sloth man is a large descendant of
the tundra dweller that imitates the now
extinct Meggathereum. It is large and
heavy, slow, yet still dangerous in its
own way. Despite having evolved in an
environment free of predators, shifts in
nature have occurred which mean that
they must now coexist with the spike
tooth. This is a smileon-like future
human that has begun to prey on the
sloth men. But the inexperienced among
the spike tooths can themselves fall
prey to the sloth men, getting crushed
by their enormous bulk if they're not
careful. The fisheater is a goblin-like
species that is a descendant of the
temperate woodland dweller, as is the
desert runner, who have diverged greatly
due to the pressures of their respective
environments. The tree dweller is an
evolved form of the tropical tree
dweller and is aroreal and slothlike.
5 million years hence, the descendants
of Jimes Smoot and his space fairing
brethren finally return. However, they
are completely unrecognizable as humans
and they themselves do not recognize
Earth as their place of origin. They
don't see it as returning home. They see
this world as just another resourcerich
planet to mine and ring dry. They soon
set about genetically modifying the
creatures of the Earth, the future human
descendants, turning them into grotesque
and freakish forms for their own use.
The engineered pack animals are bred and
augmented with mechanical parts to be
used as beasts of burden. The food
creatures are made from the hosts and
designed as blubbery monstrosities that
serve as a food source. And the
engineered workers have been created
from the temperate woodland dwellers
themselves also augmented with machine
parts to undertake simple tasks and
operate machinery. And eventually, when
all had seemingly been extracted from
the Earth, the interstellar humans left
to seek out new worlds to ravage.
However, they hadn't taken everything
that the Earth had to offer. Deep in the
depths of the ocean, the aquatic has
remained undetected. the sole surviving
future human species. These manityike
creatures seem poised to one day
reemerge from the oceans and begin to
colonize the surface which belonged to
their distant ancestors in the eons to
come.
If you enjoyed this video on man after
man and you want a deeper dive, you can
check out my full reading of the book
which can be seen here or you can watch
my other video where I explain in
greater detail each species found in the
book. Thank you for watching. This has
been the Bewarecast and I'll catch you
in the next video. Take care.
